astronomers have discovered more than a dozen planets with conditions conducive to life, a discrepancy has emerged between how these worlds are categorised as either ‘potentially habitable with surface waters’ compared with odds of ‘potentially habitable with subsurface liquid water’ (see ‘A dry world’).
As the planets generally orbit close to the equator in the ‘habitable zone’ – with ‘HabZons’ as others have unofficially dubbed these – astronomers can determine whether the planets have surface water. However, with planets close to the equator, all water below the surface remains a boiling hot liquid, leading some astronomers to categorise the likelihood of subsurface liquid water, rather than surface water – and consequently the odds of subsurface microbes – as higher.

With verbal communication prohibited, KGH had no idea the gunman was on the loose, nor that a city had declared a state of emergency to contain him.
Hospital officials are prohibiting verbal communication until the hospital can determine the scope of the situation and how to communicate with the public and media effectively, according the Health Services Ontario document.

the reason the keto diet works so well isn't so black and white. We explained all the reasons the keto diet can have a big impact on everyone’s body earlier this year, but just what is it exactly? The keto diet is all about getting your body into a metabolic state called ketosis, where you shift your body from using glucose (a form of sugar) and your favorite cookie as fuel and start using ketones (a type of acid), the byproducts your liver produces when your body breaks down fats into energy, as your primary source. Yes, keto diets are a little more challenging compared with other types of diets since you have to drastically limit your carbohydrate consumption.

Wearing a wide-brim hat, a double-breasted jacket and a serious expression, Duvalier visited a decade-gone ruin with Haiti's postwar recovery director, First Lady Michèle Duvalier, his stepsister, Yvette Duvalier, aid workers, and a television crew. As the group made its way up the stairs of the ruins, the French outcrops below bared a stark revelation: Duvalier, the former strongman dubbed the Little Tsar in a country with no other world capitalism, had yet to secure sufficient financing for a needed cleanup.

poetry of Coleridge (actually _Poetry by itself is nothing_.)
We are accustomed to the idea of a virgin forest containing a subterranean stream of water babbling to itself and leading sotto voce into a dark abyss. For the poet the subterranean stream emanates at the subnargaean level below the surface of the ground connecting the surface with the interior by the divided root of the surface. Apart from the repeatable factor we recognize in the subterraneaneous stream a factor which gives the stream a constant direction, a godlike fixity extending beyond the experience of surface men. We conceive of the knots of the standing timber as the deeper kernels or watchers or hearers.
E. A. Biron

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; the country is renowned across the world for its maternal mortality rates (which are also some of the worst in the world).
Despite the reputation for providing top-notch medical care – the reason sports stars and the general population flock to America to seek attention – America’s maternal mortality rates (which are the deaths that take place between pregnancy and pre-pregnancy) are some of the worst in the world, across women’s different socioeconomic groups. Various other organisations, like the Centers for Disease Control (CDC) agree with the Harvard study that maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation – except for the United States.

WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as astronomers have discovered more than a dozen planets with conditions conducive to life, a discrepancy has emerged between how these worlds are categorised as either ‘potentially habitable with surface waters’ compared with odds of ‘potentially habitable with subsurface liquid water’ (see ‘A dry world’).
As the planets generally orbit close to the equator in the ‘habitable zone’ – with ‘HabZons’ as others have unofficially dubbed these – astronomers can determine whether the planets have surface water. However, with planets close to the equator, all water below the surface remains a boiling hot liquid, leading some astronomers to categorise the likelihood of subsurface liquid water, rather than surface water – and consequently the odds of subsurface microbes – as higher.

Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems of large mid-green leaves heavily rimmed with small fleshy leaves. Over the summer it makes a flattened mop-like cushion and in the spring flowers with small tubular light purple flowers that are slightly darker purple on the throat the flowers age to soft purple and are distributed in loose umbrella-like clusters. It is self-cleaning, no deadheading needed, and compost well when older.
An excellent accent plant for a cool well-drained border that receives full sun these are well worth the time to collect the seeds.

GENEVA, Mar 18 2013 (IPS) - The current growth model is not sustainable. Neither the green economy nor alternative sources of energy can prevent global warming. Solutions will come from a more profound overhaul that includes changes in the world agriculture system.
Like other hotly debated crises, such as the euro zone sovereign debt mess or the adequacy of the proposed ‘super tax’ levied on the world’s richest people by France, the greenhouse effect is a systemic failure, as the famed German physicist Max Planck (1858-1947) aptly put it.
An economy geared towards continuous growth with a global expansion of credit and technology (as illustrated by the explosive advance of globalisation and monetarism in the late 20th Century) may show results for a while – if you intend to throw the dice, you can not refuse the consequence – the boom and bust cycle.

Smartphones can play a very positive role as a new tool with ophthalmologists, shows a new study conducted by the Emory University.
Smartphones can be extensively used by ophthalmologists to visualise the condition of a diabetic patient and also control the condition with the help of some tools that can help them take measurements and control screening.
The technology can also help them take the responses of the patients during the diabetic screening tests and monitor the response.
Such a technology can also help take the history of the diabetes condition of the patient and also the response towards the medication, says Alfred Sommer, the ophthalmologist researcher recently writing a paper in the issue of the Ophthalmology published in May.
With the spread of diabetes and the successes of other researchers in the field, the technology and intensity of screening for diabetes are increasing.
With the strong population burden of the diabetes, the clinicians are also interested in the use of the existing technology to facilitate screening.

PARIS (Reuters) - Finding friends and meeting new ones could become even more important uses for global positioning chips than getting from A to B as the technology spreads to cellphones in coming years.
Compass functions are already commonplace on smart telephones such as the BlackBerry range made by Research in Motion Ltd (RIM.TO) and the Pearl flip phone made by Nokia (NOK1V.HE), but location services have yet to catch on widely beyond Internet dating sites.
An audience of more than 400 people showed little fear of the technology on Thursday at a technology show held in the awe-inspiringly grand setting of the Louvre museum, much of whose Louia XIII chateau interior had a Baroque dance floor strewn with computers.
Asked how they felt about the idea of people finding out their location just by talking on a telephone, some 400 people voted with their feet, standing to show how the technology made them feel about the idea.

A neutrino event, identifiable by the rings of Cerenkov radiation that show up along the photomultiplier tubes lining the detector walls, showcase the successful methodology of neutrino astronomy. This project is led by David Wark at the University of Chicago, Shigeki Kakizaki and Albert Jackson at the University of Illinois at Chicago and the Argonne National Laboratory, and Mike Francis at the University of Chicago.
In order to create these images, all of the particle-acceleration facilities submit a composed image of the entire sky to the group, and the group selects a couple of patches where the event is particularly prominent. Those images are taken separately, and then the images are "mashed" together into a composite sky image. Above are the sky images displayed as red, green and blue (RGB) images for the three facilities (abbreviated Kronos (University of Chicago), KEK (university of Japan), INFN (university of Italy).

MUMBAI (Reuters) - Foxconn Technology is in talks to manufacture Apple’s iPhone in India, government officials said, in a move that could lower prices in the world’s No.3 smartphone market by expanding competition.
Foxconn said Chief Executive Terry Gou had asked a senior executive to discuss the plan with government officials during a visit to India earlier this month, people directly involved in the discussions said earlier this week.
Although a decision is not yet final, the move would represent the biggest expansion yet of the world’s largest contract electronics maker into India, a market forecast by some analysts to overtake the United States in the worldwide smartphone share with a compounded annual growth rate of close to 100 percent.
India has very few large scale electronics factories – compared with close to 200 in China alone – that can supply the kind of volume needed to manufacture the widely distributed Apple products.

A cynic would answer nothing, would condemn the personal gesture of writers and artists as a luxury born of the times of the Enlightenment, the escapism of a good heart. The friend of poetry will say that the words crafted —this last one the term proposed by Mahmoud Darwish— can make a difference in the world�s collective mind, can make a small revolution through the beauty the language is able to create in the best of times.

Center-right parties have won a majority of seats in Europe's Parliamentary elections, the results of which were released today. If you thought the financial crisis had given capitalism a bad name, election results show E.U. politicians are hoping people have forgotten about the Soviet Union.
Chancellor Angela Merkel's Christian Democrats (CDU) performed particularly badly, receiving just 34 percent of the votes cast in the German national elections, the same numbers they had during the German Parliamentary election of 2005. However, despite the fact that the CDU and Christian Social Union (CSU) – the Bavarian Christian Democrats – are polling numbers similar to the Green Party, the strong right-wing parties had a major impact on the German conservative electorate's decision making.
The Green Party's subsequent rise, the result of what journalist Kay Böhme called slow and careful maneuvering, refers to the Green Party's weakening of their left-out provisions and development of socially relevant topics, like poverty and the value system of the elderly.

LONDON, May 16 (Reuters) - The pesticide glyphosate, sold by Monsanto in its Roundup weed killer product and widely used in agriculture and by gardeners, does not cause cancer, a European Union officials said on Thursday after a review triggered by disputing studies.
Recent evaluations have cast doubt on the carcinogenicity of glyphosate. Regulatory decisions are taking into account the designation of glyphosate by the International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC) as “probably carcinogenic” last year.
On the other hand other big studies have failed to show the chemical causes cancer either directly or indirectly.
Those opposing the chemical are also hoping to see the E.U. encourage the spread of organic agriculture, particularly biofuels such as corn-based ethanol. The decision has the potential to trigger marketing campaigns by both anti-chemical groups and pro-industry supporters.
A separate European Union review announced last November found glyphosate did not cause long-term harm to farm workers.

APPLETON – Ed Berthiaume, news director at The Post-Crescent, will step down from his post early next year after 29 years with the news organization.
Berthiaume, 58, announced the decision Wednesday evening to Post-Crescent Executive Editor Jean Francois Mayeur and other staff members at the company’s offices in the eastbound stretch of Main Street.
His final day will be May 20, when Berthiaume becomes executive editor-at-large.
Berthiaume, the fifth executive editor during Mayeur’s leadership since 2005, will continue to cover the economy and politics for the newspaper and offer leadership in the area of employee development and sufficing the mental health needs of northeast Wisconsin.
Working with the newsroom, the news director leading the charge into a digital age, Berthiaume also helped launch the contractor and developer database, the three-tiered system implemented across the publishing divisions across the parent company Gannett Co. The Buzz: Palomar clearing land off Hilltop Drive. Here's why.
The Buzz: A piece of land off Hilltop Drive is getting cleared. Here's why.
Dirt, and lots of it — 107 tons worth — is coming to a parcel near Hilltop Drive.
Palomar Coal Company Inc. said it received a special mining permit from the city of Bradenton yesterday allowing bulk removal of the sand.
The permit authorizes the removal of one acre of sand "at a depth of at least three feet below the upland surface," according to the permit document.
What is the purpose? Lucas Cooke, corporate communications manager with the parent company, cited a recently finalized bridge project, as well as a Wiles Road improvement project, as the reason the sand had to be cleared.
The sand removal project will be handled by a Bradenton engineers, Sievers and Associates Inc. according to the city timeline.

Persistent weakness in the eurozone economy will cause imports and exports through North Europe ports to decline this year, a new report predicts.
“We are seeing weak consumer demand and a consequent impact on the carriers who persist with a surplus of ships on the market compared with the reduced demand in the market,” GAC stated.
As a result, the port of Rotterdam – the largest port in the Netherlands – will experience a weak first half in the year, the company reported.
Some segments are likely to continue the uptrend: the chemical segment is in a sluggish recovery, some agricultural products are also showing some improvement with a slight improvement in global agriculture prices.
Market challenges though are stagnant industrial demand and decreased petrochemical activity.
With volume expected to come into the Rotterdam area close to the seasonal average with a slight uptick in the second quarter compared with a similar period last year, May Container traffic had fallen by -2.0pc, with the Euro debt crisis continuing to damp the economic recovery.

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Middle Ages. As the self-appointed bishop of Athens, a rare circumstance in the history of the Greek church, he founded the Christian Academy with Erasmus.
His collected works, the so-called Chreia, exhibit a continuity with Plato and show a striking superiority to all other philosophers of the time, showing a depth equal to the greatest Christian theologians of the late antiquity (see St Basil the Great and St Ambrose). Of Proclus' treatment of Plato, James Hillman said:
Proclus undertook the task of Plato in a way Plato himself had restricted himself. Proclus would take Plato seriously; get to know him completely (he wrote a biography of Plato) and seemed to live Plato into himself.

Centralizing the procurement process, diversifying supplier portfolios and assessing the capabilities of each manufacturing partner will allow enterprises to mitigate the impact of or eliminate product recalls.
In 1986, one of the world’s largest food companies discovered a major problem with one of the most common chemicals used in its manufacturing processes – the chemical substance ammonium benzoate.
Ammonium benzoate had the potential to turn into a carcinogen when heated to high temperatures – the same temperatures commonly seen during the manufacture of common food products.
As a result, the chemical substance was banned from the menu of a major conglomeration of leading soft drink and oil companies – the seventh largest in the world – with more than 200 subsidiaries in more than 200 countries worldwide.
Although a potential carcinogen, the chemical substance was actively used as a preservative during the canning of colas, row crop spraying, hot sauces, canned fruits, canned fish, canned seafoods, canned sauces

KEI KECIL, Indonesia: It is believed by many on the Kei Islands that some of their earliest ancestors came from Bali, braving the long expanses of sea to the west.
Those original inhabitants the Anggab, also fought a deific dragon, the god Kali Kali Kami.
Like all fights with a dragon – battles with the sea – no one could ever win, so the Anggab made a peace treaty with Kali Kali Kami, and from then on, the dragon image always sat next to the kings in the Lapangan, a durian shaped part of the capital tombersali’s village council house as the village sages and the village chief were known.
As the dragons of village fable usually are, Kali Kali Kami was a sea god with six legs and a three-pronged comb.
In Bangarang, one of the southern islands, the god – or more likely a goddess – Kikorori was also made, just with a more buxom frame.

Renting an apartment with bad credit may not be easy. Many large apartment complexes owned by corporations now require credit checks and will refuse applicants who do not meet their standards. Even if you have the income to pay for the apartment, if the owners deem your credit to be poor enough, they may disregard your other credentials altogether.
Properties owned by small landlords are more flexible with their rental criteria –they may not require credit checks. However, the downside is that you have reduced bargaining power with the small landlord because you have competition for other rental properties online and other factors you can control (for example, having a strong credit score).
One final suggestion – you should also factor in the cost of the security deposit (saying the apartment is affordable would mean you have a stabilized income to pay bills and other recurring costs).

Officials have apparently been discussing the idea with the White House for months though the plan has not yet been finalized.

Currently, the major urban mobile networks (Verizon, Sprint, AT&T, T-Mobile and a few smaller providers) license broad sections of the airspace for large territories from the FCC with a perpetual license to operate until the license is withdrawn by the FCC. Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments. People don’t want the burden of sorting a large volume of letters that come with the wrong return address on the back, so make the task easier for everyone involved. Follow these additional suggestions and your letter will get you a response a lot quicker!
One of the most important facts you have to know about mailing a letter is the format your return address must have to comply with the standards required by the U.S. Postal Service.
Mailing letters with a return address requires the following format to be legal to mail (and make your letter more effective):
Only the words ‘Return Address’ below your return address are required on the envelope
Any additional words are optional
Name or Company

“DID I really just decide to have fish and chips for lunch?” Humans have been wrestling with such questions for millennia. Maybe not about the fish ‘n’ chippy but philosophers have long pondered whether humans have the freedom of choice or are slaves to the past?
Phileas Fogg (played by David Niven) completes his journey and reaches the International Date Line (Photo: Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation)
We now have the technology to investigate whether we are slaves, not to the past or the present, but to the future.
It may sound a strange statement, but the fact is the world around us – our planet – likes to travel backwards. People are caught off guard on fundamental issues like the direction of time.
One major study recently showed just how often people are wrong about the true direction of time. We are all so accustomed to looking back that the idea that time moves in the other direction baffles us (See experiments below.) What we call ”the present moment” other humans call the ”now.”

Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause these infections.
Clarithromycin can help control infections that affect the respiratory tract (e.g., calf, throat, tonsils, sinuses, airways, ears), the urinary tract (e.g., bladder infections), the soft tissues (skin and muscles), or the sex organs (pelvic area, urethra) or other bodily locations where bacteria are growing and causing the infection.
The usual recommended adult dose of clarithromycin for respiratory tract infections is 250 mg, taken twice a day. For soft tissue or skin bacterial infections other than tonsilitis, the typical recommended adult dose of clarithromycin is 500 mg taken twice a day. University of Delaware researchers found these responses are less active compared to the response seen with only elevated CO2 — with decreasing acidic conditions, nitrogen uptake also decreases.
This important new discovery directly links the ocean’s decreased nitrogen uptake to elevated ocean nitrous oxide (N2O) since emissions by the ocean increased after the Preindustrial Age. PROFESSOR Peter Higgs of Edinburgh University may now stand as a scientific legend alongside the likes of Newton, Oppenheimer and Einstein.
But the Noble laureate-in-waiting is far from the boffin-like creation people have made him out to be. Indeed, reportedly cool and self-deprecating, he admits rarely completing a whole chapter of a book – unless a deadline was forcing him on – and going through not one, but three divorces.
Peter Ware Higgs – who turns 86 this Thursday – was born in Newport-on-Tay into a prosperous Edinburgh merchant family and attended Edinburgh Academy, where he was ‘slow and uncertain [and] sometimes [feeling] distinguished more by the helpfulness of my friends than the brilliance with which I did well enough for survival’, according to a quote from 2004 meet the Nobelist project.

London: Prime Minister Theresa May said on Sunday she would not be derailed from leaving the European Union (EU) no matter how dramatic the political and economic fallout and urged the bloc to spare the British people the "harm that all this is causing".

The Boy Scouts of America’s blanket ban on gay adult leaders could end Monday when a top policy-making board plans to vote. Church-sponsored Scout units, however, could be allowed to maintain the exclusion.
The big vote by the national board isn't the final word in the fight over sexual orientation, however.
The victors of a lawsuit that a judge declared a national fraud could issue a decision ordering the Boy Scouts to accept the affirmation bans of nine Scout groups and several individuals.
A three-judge panel at the Cincinnati-based 6th Federal Circuit Court of Appeals recently upheld a judge’s decision that the national Scouts had banned the bans unfairly.

Nuance Communications has announced that IP Australia will become the first organisation across the Asia Pacific region to add next generation automated machine learning and human-assisted artificial intelligence (AI) capabilities to its widely successful Alex online virtual assistant.
Alex is IP Australia's self-service virtual Avatathe resulting from a successful partnership with Nuance launched in late 2015 to offer a range of services to IP owners looking for simpler and more streamlined services.

A hoax Facebook virus is spreading rapidly across the social network.
Many users have been hoodwinked into forwarding an inaccurate warning about the spread of non-existent malware that claims a girl committed suicide after clicking a malicious link.
The false message preys upon the fear people have for young people falling victim to stranger danger.
Facebook security expert Brian Krebs explained the ploy to make people spread the malicious hoax.
“Bad actors are taking a bunch of screen captures posted on Facebook with people talking about Facebook malware and are inserting images of ‘lovesick’ kids into the pages, making them appear they are directly related to the sappy notes in the images,” Krebs wrote for his Security Leader blog.
“In actuality, the notes are nothing more than text from screen captures of Facebook pages. We are finding the fake images are tooling around hacking toolkits available on the Web, allowing hackers to make the alteration as part of a pre-programmed process”.

President Bidhya Devi Bhandari is leaving for New York tomorrow, leading a delegation to the High-Level Event on Women in Power being hosted by the President of the UN General Assembly Maria Fernanda Espinosa Garces.
President Bhandari is attending the event on the sidelines of the 73rd session of the UN General Assembly (UNGA).
She will deliver a speech at the event, a press release by the President Secretariat said.
During the event, President Bhandari will also have meetings with the heads of state of Ireland and Tanzania, as well as with a number of other world leaders, according to the President Secretariat.
She will also take part in a meeting with the female head of states on the sidelines, according to the release.
President Bhandari arrived in New York on Sunday.
She visited the United States in September.

CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik Abdul Latif, a columnist for the luxury borders outdoor magazine Information Age, was taken into custody after publishing a book last September called "Assessment of the Economic Reform Program", the sources and his wife said. Latif made no bail.
Egypt's General Intelligence Service had ordered the arrest after the poorly distributed magazine, published in English, sold copies in the streets of the capital Cairo despite a law banning the distribution of any books except with official approval.
Security services have often jailed people they deem are spreading the word in the Arab world's most populous country.
An official at the GI group was on vacation and could not be immediately reached for comment.

Stephen Leone & Daniel Neumark, Attosecond Physics Laboratory, UC Berkeley.
he entire semiconductor industry, not to mention Silicon Valley, is built on the propensity of electrons in silicon - the backbone of the modern economy - to self-organize into a solid "electronic viscosity," flinging themselves along. These flinging feats have a limiting time and a speed limit beyond which electron self-organization is fractal: a delay in electron flinging sets the time scale, the viscosity the slow time scale flinging limit.
We reveal a new time scale visualized as the broad tail of a distribution of the flinging time of electrons in a solid. The histogram splits into a bimodal distribution of probabilities with a broad slow-flinging tail reminiscent of the slow jittering time scale distribution of a bird dipping a beak into a stream.
We microscopically invoke the microinstability of the electron distribution in a solid, successfully treating strong onset transients and gradual slow time scale electron system flinging. Ide

LONDON (ICIS)--Italy-headquartered energy group Eni is readying its Ravenna plant for a 50% capacity expansion during maintenance in August, a company source said on Tuesday.
A project to double the site's output to a projected 2.68 million tonnes a year (mtpa) is “progressing well”, according to Eni, building on a greenfield expansion that more than doubled the facility’s output last year.
Expansion work at the 500,000 bbl/day plant will continue until the completion of the project in 2020, Eni said earlier.
During the work the refiner will operate at 60-80% of its total capacity compared to the current 50%.
Eni sees no impact for rubber came SOC (secondary / recovered / reclaimed feedstock oil) prices during the maintenance, the source said..

Learning how to answer tough interview questions can help you get the job you want.
Interview questions that ask you what you will contribute to the company are designed to help employers weed out the best applicants. Your answer to this important question may provide the key reason why you get the job some other applicant doesn't get.
With all the burgeoning advances in technology these days, motivation is the factor that can either make you excel or just average with your work. Being a worker who loves his/her job may be a sign you can always take on more challenges no matter how tough they are. Employers are fishing for these types of workers so a good answer to the one above can get you the upper hand.
During the final stages of the interview you can be asked how you feel you fit with the organization's corporate culture and their corporate vision. Interviewers ask these types of questions to see how well you are in sync with the organization you are applying with. Being in touch with the attainment of the organization's objectives and visions gives you an idea how important your performance can make a big impact to the organization.

Aduro Biotech is laying off more than a third of its workforce in a restructuring intended to keep its focus on its cancer drugs now in clinical development.
The corporate shakeup will cut the Berkeley, Calif.-based firm’s workforce, across all three facilities, from more than 100 people to 66 people, Chief Executive Angela Hoppes announced April 20.
“Aduro is cutting jobs in order ‘to continue to operate within its cash position while fulfilling the steps needed in the clinic to advance one of the world’s most innovative cancer therapies,’ according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing Thursday,” the San Francisco Business Times reported.
Hoppes explains the clinical trials required to get the drug approved for sale have disrupted the company’s commercialization plan. “We will continue vigorously (to advance) our clinical programs into late-stage evaluations,” she wrote in the letter to employees.

Abu Dhabi Police will enforce lower speed limits during hazardous weather conditions from this Sunday.
The force said reduced speed limits will be posted on electronic signboards on roads and sent out by SMS, the Arabic language WAM news agency reported on Saturday.
Officers will operate a three-day-long traffic stop programme on Monday morning to see if the reduced limit of 80 km per hour can be effectively moved into the adjoining high-volume roads to make way for pedestrians.
This strategy allows the reduced speeds to gain adoption into the sub-standard limit of 60km per hour recommended late July but yet to be widely implemented, four months after the varying mandatory limits went into effect.
Abu Dhabi Police intend to continue with the authorised reduced zone, adding tweets in Arabic from the force’s Facebook page and the hashtags #RoadsAreForHuman and #WeAreAllHiring to the ‘for human’ canter.

Lloyd J. Hull, a loving World War II veteran and Pearl Harbor survivor who spent the last three decades improving the Greenwich community’s wellbeing, died on Sept. 26 after a long battle with dementia. He was 92.
Hull is survived by his loving wife of 63 years, Helen (Hilliard); daughter, Gloria (Hull) Kozubal; grandchildren, Alyssa (Hull) Savocchia and Dana Kozubal; three brothers, Owen (WWII), Paul (Korean War veteran) and David (Vietnam War veteran); a cousin, Gedalia (US World War I veteran), and cousin Jane Audas.

BOSTON (AP) — An Amtrak employee suffered an apparent heart attack and later died after a train struck a piece of construction equipment near where he was working early Thursday morning, officials said.
The Albany, N.Y.-to-New York train was en route to Moorestown, N.J., with about 150 people aboard when the accident occurred at 5:50 a.m. Thursday just south of the Back Bay train station, Amtrak officials said.
Boston firefighters said the Amtrak employee had collapsed near the tracks. four people aboard the train and one near the tracks were injured, but all are expected to survive their injuries.
A woman standing near the tracks with a pizza slipped in liquid and attempted to get up and slip and fall into the tracks, according to Bridget Looby who said she watched the train accident as she broke the glass in the frame shop she owns across the causeway from the Back Bay train station.
Deputy Fire Chief Paul Perrault said the Amtrak worker appeared to have had a heart attack.

Colorado legislators have narrowly voted in a bill that would establish state-run financial services for marijuana sellers, in an effort to ease the cash-only burden afflicting commercial weed distributors.
The bill passed the House yesterday with a vote of 37-26, just one more than the 36 votes needed to secure final approval. An additional green light from the state senate is required in order to make the law effective.
If the bill passes the senate as well, the Cannabis Businesses Registry Act—approved in both the House and the senate—would establish the Department of Revenue as the single state agency licensing commercial cannabis (for both medicinal and recreational use).
As well as institutionalizing marijuana for the state of Colorado, the creation of a dedicated administrative nerve center for legal weed in the state’s capital would enable the legislation committee to keep close tabs on the growth of legalized marijuana distribution in the region.

Bangalore: In the U.S., top outsourcing customers such as Bank of America and several local governments are asking vendors such as TCS, Infosys and Wipro to deliver more projects locally. These global accounts have asked the companies to build captive units close to the clients to demonstrate technology competence and delivery time.
Early last year, the consortium of global captive technology services providers (ITOP group) -- Infosys, Wipro, TCS, Syntel and Cognizant -- expressed reservations about these local service requirements.
The group feared a global aggregate project value would plummet leading to exorbitant bidding and reduced profitability.
ITOP was, however, persuaded into submission after the Indian government kicked off its own national plan to lure global clients by guaranteeing them local technology service providers in return for approving ready-to-build shop floors for global clients so their captive units can start on time.

It is a nightmare scenario hospitals must be prepared for, although they hope those preparations will never be used.
On Monday, that nightmare came to Kingston General Hospital when the sound of gunshots shattered the verbal communication silence across the Emergency Program (EPI).
A verbal communication silence means a hospital receives no information, until the powers-that-be feel the crisis can be communicated safely, according to a Health Services Ontario document, “Understanding the unique challenges strategic communication present during a major event.”
With verbal communication prohibited, KGH had no idea the gunman was on the loose, nor that a city had declared a state of emergency to contain him.
Hospital officials are prohibiting verbal communication until the hospital can determine the scope of the situation and how to communicate with the public and media effectively, according the Health Services Ontario document.
“Decisions are made and driven about disseminating the verbal communication event small segments at a time,” the information says. “This a fluid communication plan that can be dynamic in many situations.”

Utah's overall score from the study stayed the same compared to last year, with a score of 0.08 compared to the national average of 0.07.
Kevin Brownell, executive director of the Kem C. Garden group of charter schools, told KSL that 0.01 isn't exactly a significant difference.
In the last 10 years, the score has not gone up a single point in the state, Brownell said.

Nearly 50 years of protests, lawsuits and ballot battles over low-income housing have made San Francisco a nationwide model for efforts to keep urban America from becoming home to only the very rich or the very poor.
Early settlement of the Gold Rush lasted no more than a dozen years, propelling greater numbers of people into the systemic poverty that had long afflicted the Southern states of the cotton south. A decade after thousands flocked into the Bay area after the discovery of gold—in some circumstances taking away the slave population with them—San Francisco was one of the least affordable cities in the nation.
SF Gate’s Michael Rosencheck noted that after the great “panic” period, in 1909, more than a quarter of the population lived below the poverty level going into World War II. Nearly half of the people lived below the poverty level during the depression years leading into the war. The US economy “remains strong”, the Federal Reserve chairman, Jerome Powell, told Congress on Tuesday as he signaled the central bank is on course to carry on gradually increasing interest rates in the coming months.
In his first back-to-back appearances at Capitol Hill after the Fed’s decision this month to lift its benchmark interest rate a quarter-point to a range of 2% to 2.25%, Powell said the “gradual” policy tightening that began in December with a quarter-point increase also began a couple of months earlier with a small intensification of the bank’s balance sheet reduction – also referred to as ‘quantitative tightening’ – after a pause seen during the final months of the Obama administration.
Under the leadership of Fed chair Janet Yellen, the central had described the tapering down of the balance sheet – where the Fed withdraws excess capital from banks – as a ‘normalization of monetary policy’.

A message in a bottle that washed up more than 108 years after it was thrown into the sea may be the world's oldest, a marine association has said.

U by Uniworld has said its ship, The B, will be moving to central Europe for the 2020 season.

2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some create their own sites and services, a large segment of the population relies on hosting providers to make their sites go live.
As the interior unit of a hosting company, the reseller subsidiary allows the parent company to make more profit by providing servers to the public without purchasing additional machines.
As a reseller, you can create a small business without purchasing your own servers and mine the potential for future profit with services such as pre-sold hosting contracts.
This can be done in one of three ways.
An affiliate marketer uses a web site to direct customers to a web hosting provider, the parent company. For every client who purchases a service through the affiliate, the parent company pays a small commission.
A proxy server system, the affiliate controls a control panel can create a separate virtual server account with parent company using a license as a proxy.

It recently dawned on me that it has been nearly nine long years since my wife and children moved back to India. Living on my own hasn’t been easy. While mundane, everyday issues like food had understandably been the order of the day, having deeper conversations with my son was the biggest challenge.
A parent’s struggle isn’t just to attain a school leaving certificate, a college degree or a professional diploma either. There are other equally daunting challenges to surmount that can make or mar a child. My more pressing concerns have been how do I let him choose the right partner, so he can have a happy family life, with kids of his own? How can I make him a really big winner?

The proxy for luck can’t just be clean fines either; a happy family and long relationships can’t just hinge on external supports either.

The rate of babies who die during their first year of birth has improved nationally in the last decade, but in recent years, improvement in this key public health metric has plateaued.
New data released by the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention indicate the national Neonatal Mortality Rate – the number of baby deaths during the first 28 days after birth – decreased from 2.9 deaths per 1000 live births during the time frame 2000–2002 to 2.1 during the time frame 2008–2010 (following a small bump up from 3.0 during the time frame of 2003–2007). The decrease was not experienced equally across the country; for example, the Neonatal Mortality Rate for Mississippi remains above the national average despite a strong improvement during the time frame studied, falling seven percentage points to 3.9 during the time frame of 2008–2010.

(CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells have up to 100 times more telomeres, the protective micro-structure on the ends of chromosomes that make genes work and keep replication from going haywire; the age or lifespan of an elephant corresponds with longer telomeres across the population.
For comparison, the average human’s telomere lengthening slows down during the teens, with the average telomere getting the most microscopic repairs in the age range 60 to 70.
Elephants have big jumbles of telomeres that are akin to a big ball compared with the human version, which is more the size a pea.

Yogis may be enjoying a surprising benefit when they unroll their mats and strike a pose. A new study finds that just 20 minutes of hatha yoga stimulates brain function.
Researchers from the Division of Life Sciences at the University of Warwick observed the impact of hatha yoga on preteen students. For six weeks students practised hatha yoga on two consecutive days with a one-day break in between. The yoga poses performed varied significantly as one session addressed specific bodily bodily corrections (asana), the other a more gentle form (relaxation).
During the study students attempted a range of yoga poses from striking a wide-legged standing poses (tadasana) to more challenging visceral poses (virasana - the peaceful sitting posture). The students performed these poses twice a session lasting 30 minutes a time.

New analysis shows 22 of Australia’s largest companies are actively working to undermine the Paris agreement targets, betting shareholders’ money on strategies that assume global climate change action fails.
Investor action group Market Forces took a closer look at the emissions reductions timelines published by the world’s worst corporate climate polluters in Australia.
More than a dozen companies have no plans to get on track with the Paris agreement and have instead made or are considering making large purchases of emissions permits to delay emissions reductions until after the deadline in 2030.
Australia’s 22 worst corporate greenhouse polluters – the two worst-performing major groups are Origin and Santos – had an average reported emissions reduction timeline equal to more than a decade after the Paris agreement timeline of no more than four years after 2020.

This polygon shapefile contains ice observations in the Arctic region for July 3, 1980. This layer is part of the Arctic Climate System (ACSYS) Historical Ice Chart Archive. The earliest chart in the data set comes from 1553, when Sir Hugh Willoughby and Richard Chancellor, commanders of two expeditions sent out by the Company of Merchant Adventurers, recorded their observations of the ice edge. A continuous series of annual icegoing records was kept from 1650 to 1850 by the crew of a Russian coastal steamer (often incorrectly referred to as the "Annull Bay Survey") until 1850, after which records became sporadic until today's digitised version of the Historical Ice Chart Archive (HICA). Data for the visually-collected charts are available separately (see the Data Dictionary in the preface for details).

Composting is the ultimate win-win-win for gardeners.
It is recycling at its most basic, turning yard and kitchen waste into rich, organic planting material. It saves money on fertilizer and chemical purchases. It solves the problem of how to properly dispose of food scraps and other similar organic materials.
People have been composting since the beginning of agriculture and urban fires have large fires are believed to have had a similar effect. For more formal composting, Karl Christian Reichert published a general work on the subject in the late eighteenth century
Composting in the Kitchen
A general rule is to compost all kitchen waste that is not so large that it can't be handled by a small kitchen compost bin with a 1-quart (0.946L) so you don't get overwhelmed with the evidence (after a time you get pretty good at judging the size of your clumps in a hurry and the idea of making a decision at the time can stop your compost project from getting overwhelming.)

Take 5: How can we stop being jerky customers?
The customer may not always be right. What are some circumstances where they could be wrong?
In a recent trip to a grocery store, I grabbed a few items on the fly and approached the checkout clerk with a large green garbage bag full of frozen fruits. My grocery list contained a few other items from a separate checkout aisle, and the registers seemed a bit slow that morning.
"You're going to have a problem with that there," she stated with a smile.
I made a quivering noise with my mouth (honestly, I don't know what facial gesture is the most synonymous with a jerk), and just a tad more emphatic I explained, "We don't need the bags."
That seemed to surprise her a bit, as she said:
"Um? OK..."
And with that she returned to the register (which seemed odd to me because I hadn't seen anybody else with a green garbage bag).
Is there a place for human error?

Alaska's distilleries can no longer serve mixed drinks to customers, the state agency overseeing alcohol ruled Tuesday.
In a 3-1 vote, the Alcoholic Beverage Control board ordered the distilleries — Oskar Blues, Midnight Sun Brewing Co. and Anchorage Brewing Co. — to close their restaurants so the bars don't compete with other alcohol licensees.
As licensees of the three large municipalities, the distilleries are prohibited from making the transition.
The owner of the hotel where the distilleries are located objected with a plan to continue serving bar food.
The board voted to let the distilleries serve cocktails during a six-month transition period during which the owners can argue their case.
The board also upheld a penalty against a microdistillery for making a barrel-aged whiskey, forcing the distillery to recall thousands of bottles.

Stanley Karnow, the award-winning author and journalist who wrote a definitive book about the Vietnam War, worked on an accompanying documentary and later won a Pulitzer for a history of the Philippines, died Sunday morning. He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C., according to a family spokesman.
Karnow survived three serious illnesses during the average one-month span between September and May during the last three years of the Vietnam War to write the acclaimed volume Vietnam --- A History.
More recently, Karnow's Vietnam War book and a companion tape instructive a vocabulary course had a profound impact on the Vietnamese.
"Vietnamese kids were reading the book in school with the audio cassette with the vocabulary going with," a friend of Karnow, Chuck Sudetic, wrote in his recently published experience during the Vietnam War during the time Karnow was there

Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help a business professional predict potential subsequent scenarios the decision tree lies with a choice. The decision tree can take into account factors – such as weather fluctuation – leading to potential profitability drop or increase.
A decision tree starts with a question about a decision and can compile additional information about the impact the decision can have on a business. Washington State University estimates the decision tree analysis can streamline analysis processes at least 15% with its effectiveness.
A decision tree can have detailed factors with additional branches connecting to various people, resources, and locations affecting the outcome of the path to take.
A decision tree can become complex with additional layers of factors leading to a list of potential benefits or drawbacks in the decision-making process with the goal of providing the best course of action with the least potential for failure.
A decision tree brings a decision making process into more clarity with the weighing of the factor limiting potential decision making error

Rescuers in northern Myanmar called off their search for workers feared buried in a jade mine landslide, police said Sunday, with no missing people or bodies recovered.
A wall of rocks, mud and debris careered towards the mine around noon (0500 GMT) on Saturday after a small explosion, according to Sama Le Min Min, a local lawmaker overseeing rescue efforts.
"The casualty toll has yet to be confirmed, but according to insider estimates there are three missing workers with apparently no chance of survival," a police official in the mine's administrative area of Kachin reportedly said.
The area lies on the moorland border between Kachin and conflict-ridden Shan state between Myanmar (also known as Burma) and Thailand – infamous for smuggling drugs, arms and people.

Busan (South Korea) (AFP) - A Korean drama about desperate teens and a movie that exposes the hardships of daily life in the Iranian capital Tehran shared the top prize at Asia's premier movie festival Saturday.
At the Busan International Film Festival (BIFF), Iranian execution photos and a pet rat posing for burgers are the winners of the fest's big innovation prizes.
Officially the world's second largest cinema gathering after Cannes, the South Korean event bills a sheen for getting independent movies noticed as well as big screen talent in the spotlight.
A finance and distribution hub in the booming Korean cinema of the late 2000s, the annual event boasted beefing up numbers with a strong contingency from the east.
Completing the Asian tally are one Japanese and three Chinese entries from a crop of some 300 films.
Australia had the strongest showing with a dozen entries across short and features.
Asia will also feature prominently in some other major world cinema fests ready to spring into the late growing season.

Pardoned by the Pope immediately after his return to the Scottish throne after betraying his king – King John Balliol – Bruce returned the crown immediately after and remains a revered figure until the present day.

Born most likely the year previously the Hammering – Bruce’s history has equally as much cultural credence to the the Battle of Bannockburn than the Sword of Damascus and the Hammering themselves.

Lyft has pulled from service all of its on-demand electric bicycles in New York, Washington DC and the San Francisco Bay area after some riders reported issues with the brakes.
"We recently received a small number of complaints about the braking on the pedal-assist bikes and kicked them out," a Lyft spokesperson told BuzzFeed News.
She said the bikes are now being recalled so the company can replace the stock brakes with a cheaper version with a higher pedal resistance.
Lyft introduced the pedal-assist bikes in September as a more affordable option for people looking to make short trips.
Users can create a virtual queue to get a bike, getting a text message when one is ready. From there, the bikes are available in a 24-hour window and the prices vary from a couple dollars to more.
Those riding the bikes don't have to show a providence license so a helmet isn't needed either, except in California (although the company notes the "majority of users involved wore one.")

MEXICO CITY (AP) — A man was arrested Monday in the shooting death of a journalist who worked for the newspaper El Heraldo de Chiapas, and authorities were searching for three other people suspected of having ordered the assassination. The killing Saturday of Gregorio Jiménez de la Cruz increased already high fears about the safety of journalists in the western Mexican state of Chiapas.
Security video footage captured the aftermath of the assassination after Jiménez left a bar on Saturday evening and was approached from behind, by a killer posing as a companion the journalist invited outside the bar after the late hour closing time — Jiménez was normally vulnerable to alcoholism, the Chiapas prosecutor’s office said in a statement.
A relative a Jiménez told the Televisa Grupo news organization the journalist had recently discovered he had a debt with the organized crime group armed with injuries from a motorcycle accident.

ZURICH, April 10 (Reuters) - Sunrise Communications' top shareholder on Wednesday blocked plans to extend the company's right to issue fresh capital to 2021, complicating a boardroom struggle for control.
A group led by billionaire entrepreneur Marcus Jooste made the move, sunrise reported after the closing bell in Switzerland, knocking the ninth-largest telco down more than 4 percent. The board advised shareholders to vote against the motion.
Dubbed the Strategic Gestion Sarl Group (SGSO), Jooste controls Switzerland's largest telecoms operator after a yearslong campaign on the stock market.

He was also found responsible for making a comment about going to prison on a Yahoo Chat of March 2009 and also charged him with making the language in a media interview “predicated upon a criminal event that had occurred.”
Arenas did strike a deal with federal prosecutor to plead guilty to one count of possessing a loaded gun in the D.C. area airports. He is required to fulfill 200 hours of community service with the Wizards and donate the basketball shoes he wore when the gun incident occurred.
The gun was discovered when the NBA security searched Arenas at the airport.

Looking for calm? Head to Rüschlikon in Zurich, where, eight metres below the Binnig and Rohrer Nanotechnology Centre, IBM Research has six new "noise-free" labs. "The noise floor is so low you can hear other people talking across the room with senses other than your own," explains Ansar Bhana, project director.
The idea behind the facility is to get scientists doing measurements with the highest resolution possible — a factor of 10 more accuracy — and giving a more reliable perspective on the smallest potential changes possible.
IBM sees the creation of these noiseless conditions one day leading to the creation of a quantum internet — for the theorists among you a communications system in which information is handled with a sub-particle level.
When applied directly, these conditions have precluded the need for the the wanted noise to reach the outside world — with current measurements meaning noise gets into the system with the smallest impartable delay possible meaning delay must be within plus or minus a few picoseconds (10(-10) of a second).

Mounir el-Motassadeq, one of the only men sent to prison because of the 9/11 terrorist attacks, is now a free man. He was released from the maximum-security Fuhlsbüttel prison in the early morning hours after a judge ordered him released during a hearing at a local court in nearby Harburg, Die-Presse reported.
El-Motassadeq was Austrian citizen who lived as a radical Islamic preacher in Hamburg until he was convicted in a German court for a “forbidden association with the Sept. 11, 2001 terrorist attacks in the United States,” the New York Times reported.
The decision to let him go despite the fact that a German court ordered him to honor the conditions of the earlier lawsuit, including 70,000 Euros ($83,000) compensation to families of the victims made officials nervous.
“We fear that the decision of the court of the Herberge (Hamburg says the decision had legal effect) can soon be a legal obligation,” the government wrote, according to Die Presse.

Warehouse retail king Costco recently ended its relationship with American Express in favor of a new one with Visa and Citigroup. And after a bit of a bumpy start, it looks like the new deal is starting to take shape.
Costco has filed a lawsuit against the global payment organization Visa, accusing the entity of charging the stores fees to affiliate with major card providers, plus a concealed fee that the stores are required to pass into the hands of the consumers, ending up charging individuals more for using the desired payment system at Costco stores. Costco alleges these fees are unnecessary and have already threatened the functioning of the payment system affiliated with the stores.
As a result, on May 29 Costco filed a class-action lawsuit against the payment organization in a federal district court located in the Western District of Washington. In the complaint, Costco accuses the payment organization of performing anticompetitive practices and abuses of its collective dominance.
In response to the lawsuit, a spokesperson from the payment organization claimed the allegations made by Costco have been deemed false

Parents in towns at the centre of the Novichok nerve agent poisonings have been warned not to let their children pick up foreign objects.
The move comes two days after Dawn Sturgess died from picking up a counterfeit version of the World War Two anti-biological explosive.
Police have linked the poisonings with the assassination attempt on Russian double agent Sergei Skripal and his daughter Yulia, who remain seriously ill.
Thames Valley Police will issue a leaflet to parents with a cartoon to warn children against the dangers of Urbanimir, which means 'city ugly, friend of man' in Russian, the warfare chemical used to poison the couple.
Dawn, 44, and a worker in a cleaning company where the chemical had been disposed of, collapsed after touching it.
she was taken to hospital on May 30 after falling ill after making contact with the poison and died from the poisoning on Saturday morning.

Cameroon’s Anglophone crisis, which started with strikes by teachers, students and those in the legal profession in late 2016 and now includes groups calling for secession, is deepening. People from English-speaking regions in the already fractured east – the Paris of Africa – are fleeing.
President Paul Biya has deployed the military to help “quell the violence”. According to the United Nations in December 2017, most refugees are fleeing Bamenda – Anglophone in the west – the scene of recent violence and a decision by the law society to abandon the use of the French language.
Those leaving have reportedly cited the legal implications of self-abdication, so are settling in suburbs of Douala in the south. However, there are signs of more violence in those communities. On 13 March, students were reportedly the victims of a deadly anti-government demonstration by Civitas students, according to Amnesty International.

Carl Johnson, co-founder of Anomaly, a marketing communications firm and advertising agency, isn’t actually staying in Cannes. He’s staying at the historic Hotel du Cap in Antibes. Sunbathing between sushi lunches with clients in Monte Carlo, boozing in the caves of the Château romanée conti (they had nothing else to booze in a French village save chateau­romaneecot) with the likes of Nicolas Sarkozy and François Mitterand (they sell the chateau after the bureaucrats, so Anomaly likes to get there early). So how did a kid from Granby, Ontario make it all the way to the south of France with every connection and experience he possesses? Was he emboldened by the unabashed self preservationism of the beaches (where Provence begins with a pedicure in The Plage) or was the sun withering him into a quivering mass? Did the dreams he envisioned upon the caves seem a precursor to some other romance?

A Los Angeles-bound Alaska Airlines flight was forced to return to Seattle's airport Monday afternoon after an airport worker fell asleep and became trapped in the cargo hold.
Alaska Airlines said the flight had just departed Seattle for Southern California when the airplane turned around and returned to Seattle so the airline worker could be removed from the plane.
Airline officials said the worker fell asleep while helping other airport workers and became trapped in the cargo hold after the airplane secured the doors.
The airplane returned to Seattle, landed at the airport and the worker was removed after a few hours.
Alaska Airlines typically sends a flight attendant into the cargo hold during takeoff and landing of a flight, perhaps the busiest time personnel are needed aboard the plane, but a mechanic entered the cargo area Monday aboard the plane near takeoff to inspect the carriage of the flight control system.
The mechanic had just returned to the cabin when the the airplane taxied away after circling the airport several times to burn off enough fuel to return to the airport.

There is no easy option for Northern Ireland after Brexit.
Deciding on post-Brexit border arrangements between Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic is becoming an issue for which the phrase "the devil is in the detail" could have been invented.
On a number of occasions US President Donald Trump has expressed strong views about the need for a physical line on the island of Ireland (which would require the return of a corridor between north and south Antrim).
His latest, reportedly in a telephone conversation with the prime minister yesterday, threatened to be the final piece of the jigsaw towards a no-deal Brexit and invited strong words from the prime minister.
Mrs May - in a letter to Brussels leaders - went so far as to warn that if the European Union did not grant a so-called "time-limited extension", the UK would have no option other than to leave with no agreement after March 29.
Yet seven months into the two-year process we still have no clue exactly how the politician-class are making progress (or not) towards a solution that will allow the final stinging defeat of PM May in the House

Many in the media and tech industry see Uber’s decision to sell its Chinese business unit to rival Didi Chuxing as a failure for the U.S. ride-hailing giant. It’s easy to believe that analysis after more than a year of potentially crippling legal battles. But the claims are more nuanced than the Chinese business deal inched to completion during April.
Another key factor is time — how long China’s market has withstood the abrasive fraying around the Uber and Lyft world.
Uber had no intention of going anywhere until it knew the terms of the deal with Didi Chuxing (Netease Inc.’s [NTES] Taobao.com is prohibited). Both ride-share rivals are charting a course from the get-go — taking the appropriate time so the competition can contend with a global leader that pedals innovation and technology.
Some brushes with the legal system are worth the extra attention — particularly for numbers thrown around the courtroom with the purpose of putting a temporary kibosh on pointless battles.

MYRTLE BEACH, SC (WMBF) - As our world continues to advance with the help of technology, artificial intelligence (AI) has generated a lot of buzz lately in healthcare. AI healthcare providers are already saving lives and making appointments more accessible, improving the treatment experience for tens of thousands of people.
In a small study group consisting of fifteen clients, the potential impacts of AI in dermatology are projected. For example, the average time a patient was with a virtual provider (8 minutes) in the study group was a third the time they spent with a provider face to face (25 minutes).
Basically, the study says you get more, faster with the virtual dermatologist. There are also predictions that dermatologists are going to see a dip in skin cancers referred to them thanks to these virtual providers.

Northern California history buffs descended upon the train event — a major attraction in the city since the late 1980s — to take a look a the train exhibit as well as hunt for those special green coupons.
“It means a lot, a big responsibility to take this train every time the Greening of the Depot happens because people get so attached with this train. They know some of these people” — who own the trains — Greenberg said.
Amber Kent first attended the Greening of the Depot with her family a couple of years ago. As a kindergartener at the time, she went home ready to investigate how train stations operate. Nearly a decade later, Kent remains a train enthusiast.

But it's worth stepping back from Romney's specific remarks and looking at President Obama's clean-energy track record more broadly. What sorts of green jobs programs has the Obama administration spent $90 billion on?
President Obama hasn't so directly embraced green jobs—the "green shoots" image that then-candidate Barack Obama projected following his 2008 election had a particular appeal. But the administration made a number of moves in his first term—and across the 2010–12 timeframe overall—that aligned with the idea of a national clean-energy effort.
As the graphs below show, green investing has soared under the Obama administration. Another two green jobs booms may yet be ahead.
We can see the impact already: While clean energy jobs grew across the world during the past decade, the United States captured the lion's share of the global clean energy jobs boom over the past decade.

The plan also treats with the issue of how the system can be implemented as it seeks potential methods of communication with overseas partner organisations like the [UK] GCHQ (Government Communications Headquarters) – as well how to hide the technology from the general population.
"Although US allies have similar quantum Kryptographic systems deployed domestically, they are prohibited with International Telecommunication Union (ITU) law to place these quantum cryptographic networks on the International Service," claims the leaked document, with internal references telling the organisation how vulnerable the technology can potentially be, revealing how the quantum system can potentially be hacked – particularly with other means of communication that are typically more widely accepted.

It's no surprise why the keto diet has grown in popularity over the last few years; it's helped people lose weight, can fight inflammation, and may even be good for those with diabetes. But the reason the keto diet works so well isn't so black and white. We explained all the reasons the keto diet can have a big impact on everyone’s body earlier this year, but just what is it exactly? The keto diet is all about getting your body into a metabolic state called ketosis, where you shift your body from using glucose (a form of sugar) and your favorite cookie as fuel and start using ketones (a type of acid), the byproducts your liver produces when your body breaks down fats into energy, as your primary source. Yes, keto diets are a little more challenging compared with other types of diets since you have to drastically limit your carbohydrate consumption.
The keto diet isn't exactly new (having roots in the Dietmonger centers in the mid-’20s), but adhering to one

Other conditions proposed Monday by the company include:
Obtaining Green Standards status for the old building located at the corner of Capitol and Raymond
Committing $10 million annually to charitable donations in the form of cash and other donated goods
Allocating one percent of the company’s pre-tax operating income and profit to enable workers to participate in non-profit activities
Establishing summer jobs programs
Hiring more workers with disabilities

HAITIAN President General Jean-Claude Duvalier recently made a rare public appearance. Wearing a wide-brim hat, a double-breasted jacket and a serious expression, Duvalier visited a decade-gone ruin with Haiti's postwar recovery director, First Lady Michèle Duvalier, his stepsister, Yvette Duvalier, aid workers, and a television crew. As the group made its way up the stairs of the ruins, the French outcrops below bared a stark revelation: Duvalier, the former strongman dubbed the Little Tsar in a country with no other world capitalism, had yet to secure sufficient financing for a needed cleanup.

From the outlook of a planet that resides next to a quiet, relatively predictable star, the circumstances that lead to dramatic stellar explosions elsewhere in the universe can sound somewhat improbable. Some such blasts, known as supernovae, are powerful enough to emit enough thermal light radiation (heat light from the explosive debris after the explosion) to make the object responsible (or possibly responsible) glow with the intensity of a dozen of our own suns combined. Stars are cruelly beautiful monsters that can loose a fiery death throe with a final act so powerful, so violent, so destructive, that it can actually trigger the evolution of chemical processes that make up other possible planets for the forseeable future.
Most energies emitted from a supernova are emitted almost instantaneously (with some exceptions). As you can see (or touch and feel), nothing explodes so violently that the object can continue to bounce with the same characteristics seen previously. That important factor immediately means the explosion direction (with the time it takes to de-accelerate) determines the angular momentum's pointing direction. Bear with me;

I'm the HR Director for a growing manufacturing firm. I started the job in July. I report to the CEO.
As a candidate for the position I had some major concerns. Earlier this year the company had let go some procurement people and some senior management people. At the time these had been couched in the language that "improved efficiency" had required the changes.
During the interviewing process the CEO went a bit further, telling me about a plan by the senior procurement people to consolidate purchasing into a clearing house set up within the procurement group.
Basically this would have rendered the entire procurement group obsolete to the point of firing most of them.
With the consolidation plan no one else except the procurement group would have access to the vendor contacts.
And the procurement group would have a consolidated telephone system with no other connection to the outside (outside vendors are a major source of business to the company.)

(CNN) – The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention has issued guidelines for the first time on treating children with concussions, saying they will provide doctors with the “tools they need to ensure the kid comes back playing the sport.”

Dr. Ann McKee, a Boston University neuropathologist who has studied hundreds of former NFL players diagnosed with chronic traumatic encephalopathy (CTE), said a special issue of the journal Neurology published Wednesday, contains a 19-page update of clinical recommendations – the first time the recommendations have been issued since the group had been put together in 2006.
The organization had developed a clinical guideline more than a decade earlier, McKee explained.
Now more than 100 people have had chronic traumatic encephalopathy diagnosed – a condition more commonly seen in NFL players retroactively.

The Flinch author Julien Smith is giving his book away for free. Something for nothing? That's the idea. The co-author of the 2009 book Trust Agents is so intent on sharing his work that he's created a YouTube ad that explains the concept and lets you self-select your offer (or no offer) format. A sociological experiment with a capital S? Whatever the reason, human beings are a sucker for a good offer, so how many people take your offer?

“The Unruly Mystic: John Muir” explores the remarkable life and influential works of a patron saint of environmental activism. This inspirational documentary examines the connection nature and spirituality, using the life and wisdom of one of America’s greatest heroes – John Muir – to show how humans can reconnect with the earth and fulfil their true potential.
John Muir (1838-1914) is considered a father of the American conservation and environmental movement. As a naturalist (and broadly self-taught botanist and geologist) Muir had a major impact on the conservation of the United States’ natural resources. Muir made frequent trips from the United States to U.K during his long lifetime, with visits to jail in Yosemite (with the birds) and becoming a dear friend of (included) Willaim Butler Yeats.

I’ve always had an interest in colour. Coming from Scotland, where the weather often turns everything grey, I used to love how the landscape would transform when the sun came out. I had a view of the Ochil hills from my bedroom window and I made a point of stopping to have a look whenever the colours were particularly beautiful.
Photo by Nasim Naseri
Taking photographs just made common sense a few years into it all. My interest is mostly in capturing the colours: the patches of blue sky and green trees or crags can make my day so well; more so than just a photograph of a church or a stream though beautiful in their own right. Have you ever wondered why rocks margaritas tasted more alcoholic than frozen margaritas? Or whether one of the best-sellers in your favourite pub is a Brave New World? Well, the craft alcohol boom brings with it new possibilities when it comes to kegging, canning and bottling. Forget the glass bottles with the red stripe – forget taverns with fish and chips on your lap – those days are history.
During Prohibition, a time when you couldn’t get a drink anywhere, people brewed their own into kegs. Many pubs with kegs did nothing but kegs – perfecting the beers they made themselves for the audience it wanted to cater to. There are a large population of people who have a strong fixation towards ales, stouts, black ales, pilsners and IPAs – some call it a craft alcohol boom, some call it a bubble.
Things have rapidly taken a turn for the more esoteric.

What's More Important: Your Product Or Proof-Of-Concept?
I have had the luxury of meeting over 500 startups at Red Rocket Ventures over the last three years. And, typically, once a company passes the 75 percent attendance stage (partners, friends, advisor, board member, etc.) they are ready for a close review by potential investors after demonstrating a validated product.
Copyright : jorgGreiner
So, let me preface this, particularly with the caliber of the Red Rocket batch three finalists: It is rare that I have had a formal presentation that did not have the security of a beta sticker (or, more appropriate, a scale-able alpha stickers on the end of the presentation). It has a big impact on the funding potential:

Twitter just officially launched its “retweet with comment” feature, which it began testing last summer.
“Retweet with comment” allows users to embed a tweet in their own tweets, which lets them get around Twitter’s 140 character limit and expand how widely the quoted tweets are made visible across the Twitter service.
Twitter also rolled out a lot of other tweaks and enhancements to the service, with the stated goal of making tweets even more fun to create and share — particularly to the much coveted “front page” in your Facebook stream.
Twitter added control over how your timeline appears.
Now you can control how timelines are organized into lists, the groupings you can see when you tweet the ‘@’ button from a tweet, the ‘@’ button you see in your timeline after you’ve published a tweet.
Users can also choose how timelines are shown red in your timeline (i.e. people you tweeted with), gray (i.e. people you follow), black (no organization at all, leaving your timeline a mess).

In the San Antonio Independent School District, the focus is on breaking down - school size that is, as the Texas city seeks to turn its eight large public high schools (average enrollment: 2,000) into a more manageable size. Its small-school plan involves transitioning the high schools into those with no more than 900 students. Should the plan come to pass, Sagi Kesavan, SAEISD's director of the innovation strategy, says the school board aims to have all students have the chance of receiving a small school experience.
Those already getting the experience at the nine SAEISD schools currently falling into the small-school category (including the small school expansion programs across the district) are studying more in depth (and having more 1-on-1 with their teachers) while also more fully taking control of the direction of the school.

NASHVILLE, Tenn. — Jerry Reed, a popular country singer and movie actor whose larger-than-life storytelling and flashy guitar work vividly evoked Southern life, died early Monday morning at his home in Hilskintop Drive. He was 71.
Reed had recently had a stroke. Bobby Braddock, a friend of Mr. Reed's, had visited him Friday night.
"He couldn't talk with words when he had one of his crippling strokes some years ago," Braddock said Monday. "Those are the kind you don't come back from."
In a self-parody, Mr. Reed sang a version of the national anthem made particularly bizarre by a pre-rehearsal injury that made him howl just as the song approached its finale.
In earlier generations, Mr. Reed's jazzy take on the hard-core country sounds of Ernest Tubb and other Southern forebears would have opened the door for him in pop music. But the hard peddling of Southern music today is gaining both radio airplay and national success
